sen.j: 奈良茶飯（ならちゃめし）は、炊き込みご飯の一種で、奈良県の各地の郷土料理。
sen.e: "Nara chameshi" is a kind of takikomi gohan (rice boiled with seasonal ingredients) and a local cuisine in various regions of Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 江戸時代の川崎宿の名物料理だった。
sen.e: Nara chameshi was a famous food at Kawasaki-juku Station in the Edo Period.
Nara chameshi was a speciality of Kawasaki-juku Station during the Edo Period.
sen.cmt: famous food atをspeciality ofにしました。Inをduringにしました。
sen.e: Nara chameshi was a speciality of Kawasaki-juku Station during the Edo Period.

sen.j: 少量のコメに炒ったダイズやアズキ、焼いたクリ、アワなど保存の利く穀物や季節の野菜を加え、塩や醤油で味付けした煎茶やほうじ茶で炊き込んだものである。
sen.e: Nara chameishi is prepared by boiling rice with nonperishable foods or seasonal vegetables such as roasted soybeans, azuki beans, baked marons, or millets, in green tea or roasted green tea seasoned by using salt or soy sauce.

Nara chameishi is prepared by boiling a small amount of rice with nonperishable foods such as roasted soybeans, azuki beans, roasted chestnuts or millets or seasonal vegetables in green tea or roasted green tea seasoned with salt or soy sauce.

sen.j: シジミの味噌汁が付くこともある。
sen.e: It is often served with freshwater clam miso soup.

sen.j: 栄養バランスにも優れ、江戸時代に川崎宿にあった茶屋「万年屋」の名物となった。
sen.e: Nutritionally well balanced, Nara chameshi became a famous dish of a teahouse "Mannennya" which was located at Kawasaki-juku station in the Edo Period.

sen.j: 元来は奈良の興福寺や東大寺などの僧坊において寺領から納められる、当時としては貴重な茶を用いて食べていたのが始まりとされる。
sen.e: Nara chameshi is said to be originated from rice eaten at priests' residences in temples such as the Kofuku-ji Temple and the Todai-ji Temple by using tea which was valuable in those days and presented from people living in each temple's territory.

sen.j: 本来は再煎（二番煎じ以降）の茶で炊いた飯を濃く出した初煎（一番煎じ）に浸したものだった。
sen.e: Originally, rice boiled with tea prepared by used leaves was immersed in the strong tea prepared as the first decoction of the tea leaves.

sen.j: それが江戸や川崎に伝えられ、万年屋などで出されるようになったとされている。
sen.e: It is said that the recipe was introduced to Edo and Kawasaki regions, so that the dish became a menu item at Mannenya teahouse and others.
It is said that the recipe was introduced to the Edo and Kawasaki regions, and started to be served at Mannenya and other eateries.

sen.j: さらに十返舎一九の滑稽本『東海道中膝栗毛』に万年屋および奈良茶飯が登場したことで一層有名となり、万年屋は江戸時代後期には大名が昼食に立ち寄るほどの人気を博したと言う。
sen.e: The humorous novel "Tokai dochu hizakurige" (Travels on Foot on the Tokaido) written by Ikku JUPPENSHA, referring to Mannenya teahouse and its Nara chameshi, made the teahouse further famous and in the latter half of the Edo Period, Mannenya teahouse became so popular that even some daimyo (feudal lords) dropped by at the teahouse for lunch.
